title: Aesthetics of Evil
text:
Abstract
In medieval bestiaries, there are two classes of evil represented by beasts; those which deceive and those which generate fear and death. Among the first class of beasts, those which are notable for their abilities to deceive, there are three kinds of deception: these are noted by the camouflages of the chameleon, accurate imitations of the manticore, and the “seductive skills of sirens”. While we might think this to be a medieval taxonomy of epistemic harms only, the kinds of epistemic harms the medievalists worried about are not far off from contemporary epistemic harms and risks; misinformation, false and inauthentic narratives, and bullshit.

title: Gut Reactions
text:
Elements of Emotion

thoughts
body changes
action tendencies
modulations of mental processes (attention, conscious feelings)

Which is the emotion?


Theories of Emotion

Feeling Theory: emotions are simply feelings
James-Lange: bodily changes precede our emotional experiences
Somatic Theory: ( emotions are feelings \(\land\) emotional feelings are feelings of bodily changes ) \(\rightarrow\) emotions are feelings of bodily state changes
Damasio, 3 distinctions from somatic:

expanded states: emotional experiences are experiences of changes in the body, but bodily states are expanded
As-If Loop: (interenal milieu, emotions can register changes of levels of chemicals in the brain, brain can enter kind of state it would be in if various bodily changes had taken place).
emotions are not exhausted by feelings



From Parts to Theories


Hybrid Theories


Dimonsional Appraisal Theories



From Parts to Plentya

The Problem of Plenty


Coming Attractions
What are emotions?
Perceptions of patterned changes in the body.

title: Gut Reactions
text:
What is their significance?

Contribute to reasoning, action, and the election of ends.
Triggered by judgments and amenable to cultural influence.
Central to our comprehension of morality.

Consider internal systems of categorization, memory, attention, and reasoning (Processing Mode Theory):

Easier to recall events when in emotional states that are congruent with those events we are recalling (Bower 1981)
Positive emotions tend to promote the use of stereotypes (Bless, Schwarz, & Kemmelmeier, 1996)
Positive emotions help us to reason in ways that are open-minded, optimistic, and creative. Easier time problem solving novel applications of familiar materials (Isen, Daubman, & Nowicki, 1987)
Negative emotions promote more narrow attentional focus. Anxiety makes us attend to threatening objects (MacLeod & Mathews, 1991; Ohman, Flykt, & Esteves, 2001)
Sadness makes us more pessimistic and sensitive to our flaws (Alloy & Abrahamson, 1988)

Manticore

title: Black authenticity and commodified realness: effects of controlling images and colourism
text:
Controlling images “are designed to make racism, sexism, poverty, and other forms of social injustice appear to be natural, normal, and inevitable parts of everyday life” (Collins 2000, 77).


What are the purposes of controlling images?
But if we broaden the label, then controlling images are designed to justify marginalizing some members of society.


Cultural production in context: the case of rap music

White corporate owners capitalized on the realness and rawness of rap music and used the artists’ and music’s authenticity as a marketing strategy. (layb20?)


This process was finalized with mainstream consumption in the 1990s with the 1996 Telecommunications act

radio stations were consolidated from locally independent radio stations and labels to national conglomerates.
music labels were consolidated from locally independent music labels to national conglomerates.

This meant that radio airplay format and songs were standardized.
Additionally, the markets which justified these consoladations where 60-80% white [Bialik, Carl. 2005. “Is the Conventional Wisdom Correct in Measuring Hip-Hop Audience?” Wall Street Journal, May 5. Accessed May 1, 2013. http://online.wsj. com/news/articles/SB111521814339424546; Kitwana, Bakari. 2002. The Hip Hop Generation: Young Blacks and the Crises in African American Culture. New York: Basic Civitas Books.; Rose, Tricia. 2008. The Hip Hop Wars: What We Talk about When We Talk about Hip Hop And Why It Matters. New York: Basic Books.].
Artists on their part began to equate ‘artist legitimacy’ with ‘commercial success’ [Lena, Jennifer C. 2006. “Social Context and Musical Content: Rap Music, 1979-1995.” Social Forces 85 (1): 479–495.].
As a result, these artists started to sell stereotypical beliefs about blackness back to a consumer base.



Hypotheses
crumbs: 9  Black authenticity and commodified realness: effects of controlling images and colourism

title: Narrative Identity Korsgaard
text: Christine (kors89?) has argued that that Derek (parf87?)‘s Reasons and Persons defends an account of identity on which a person is primarily a locus of experience (kors89?). Kantians and Utilitarians have differeing conceptions of agency. For the Utilitarian, agency is a form of experience. As such, while the utilitarian asks ’what should be done for them?’, the Kantian asks ‘what ought they do?’. Korsgaard goes on to argue that focusing on what an agent does, rather than their experiences, will lead to a drastically different concept of identity. One which she calls ‘practical’.

title: Typecasts, Tokens, and Spokespersons
text: What kind of harm?

title: Typecasts, Tokens, and Spokespersons
text:
harms its targets as knowers
and transmitters of knowledge


Respect

harm which deprives speaker of basic Respect
Respect == Not a full object

Pohlhaus 2014, 105 “Speaker assumes a sort of ‘truncated’ or ‘circumscribed’ Subjectivity
Beauvoir 1952, status as the ‘other’



relegated to the role of epistemic other, being treated as though the range of one’s subject capacities is merely derivative [Pohlhaus 2014, 107]


Subject are reduced to attending only to that which stems from the perpetrator’s subjectivity



Epistemic “derivatization” -> Compulsory Representation -> Unique form of Epistemic Exclusion

the others capacities as a subject are reduced to attending only to that which stems from the perpetrator’s subjectivity, so that anything the victim might try to express that exceeds the range of the perpetrator’s subjectivity is actively prohibited and /or left unrecognized by the perpetrator, even while he recognizes the victim as capable of having experiences, interests, and desires. [106]

Therefore: not seen as “capable of contributing to epistemic practices uniquely, that is, from her own distinct lived experiences . . . she is not permitted to contribute in ways that extend beyond or trouble the veracity of the dominantly experienced world” [107]

But, what about only being seen as “capable of contributing to epistemic practices uniquely, that is, from her own distinct lived experiences”

[i.e., not through an ability to reason inferensially to a unique, non-normative conclusion]

and therefore, . . . “she is not permitted to contribute in ways that extend beyond or trouble the veracity of the dominantly experienced world”

A unique epistemic practice is one that is only subjectively true grounded not in universal experience, but subjective one.

The problem with PCE is not that one is not permitted to contribute in ways that are perceived to extend beyond dominant experiences; rather, the problem is that one is only permitted (and expected to) contribute in ways that are considered “unique” and “distinct”. [Davis 490]

title: Morality as Privilege
text:
Abstract
This concerns an interesting and popular assertion, that it takes a certain amount of material wealth to be a good person. I suspect that this is a project of capitalism: buy our stuff or you will be a bad person . . .

title: Epistemic Injustice
text:
Hermeneutic Injustice
Famously, Miranda Fricker develops an account of epistemic injustice that involves both testimony and hermeneutics. An important consideration here, is one’s capacity as a ‘moral’ knower where ‘moral’ knower has to do with a victim’s understanding of virtues, vices, and values that are attributed, or are not to the victim. Following (kupl20?), I argue that central to these are success or failure conditions whereby a person fails or succeeds in engaging in the imaginative ‘process of simulating’ a character’s psychological and emotional states [68]. However, while Kuplen argues the failure is due to our own imagination, I attribute it as a success condition in that these are ‘controlling images’ wherein the outcome is a form of narrative art which intends to portray characters whose mental states and experiences are the converse of that art’s audiences. I argue that this epistemic injustice makes individual who identify, or identified with such characters unintelligible to its audience.
The discussions that center around epistemic injustice focus on the moral wrongs of epistemic injustice and define these as wrongs of testimonial inference where the victim is wronged in their capacity as an epistemic knower. The victim’s credibility as an epistemic agent is diminished and as such, she is made unintelligible to a broader public. However, the wrongs do not draw enough attention to a specific kind of moral harm. Here, ‘moral’ implies ‘moral’ information, or ‘moral’ knowledge. Unlike general accounts of knowledge, moral knowledge has been understood as a kind of understanding. On the one hand, these are values that would have been instilled in the victim and that others would attribute to the victim as having. Such a harm I argue is two fold, as I will show. Not only are other prevented from understanding the victim, the victim is prevented from understanding herself. Both she and others are prevented from recognizing the victim’s moral agency.
What is the difference between harm done in regard to someone’s capacity as a knower and their capacity as a ‘moral’ knower? Related to the victim’s capacity as a moral knower, is the victim’s capacity as a person, where personhood denotes more specifically, their own moral agency, held values, and the like.
Let’s consider hermeneutic injustice.
Hermeneutic harm occurs when the victim suffers because they do not have the conceptual resources to make sense of their own experiences.
But here there are two possible concerns:
From these are derived two more:
As an example of the first possible concern, a person is victimized by an agent who holds a degree of power over her when she cannot understand that she is a victim.
We can imagine that a given victim is a patriotic member of society who throughout the course of their life, has been led to believe that it is their duty and obligation to assist law enforcement in carrying out their duties whenever possible. One day they are walking to work when they notice a police officer chasing a suspect. The suspect runs past the victim, and when they do so, the victim trips the suspect. However here the victim is harmed in their capacity as a moral agent because they are prevented from carrying out what they take to be their moral duty, assisting law enforcement in carrying out their duties. This is because little do they know, the police officer chasing the suspect is actually working as an enforcer for the mob and the suspect is actually a whistle-blower trying to escape the clutches of the mob.
Therefore, the victim is a victim just because they are prevented from doing what they intended to do, assist law enforcement in carrying out their duties. Here they are not assisting law enforcement, rather they are being victimized by a police officer working for the mob.
However the harm is ambiguous. Either it is the case that in the event that this person does not recognize their own victimization, and believes themselves to be fulfilling their duty, or they are being prevented from fulfilling their duty without realizing it. Another question stemming from this is whether this person is in a position to defend their lack of protest.
We can imagine a situation wherein she is able to defend her decision not to protest, she might say “I am not a victim because it is the thought that counts”. In such a case, is she or is she not a victim? Derivative of this then, is the fact that she cannot express her moral values in a way that is interpretable to herself, or to others. For instance, the next day she recounts her story to a friend who convinces her of her victimhood. If they do convince her, is it from a position of power? Which structures, social or otherwise are responsible for this specific ability or inability?

title: Epistemic Injustice
text:
Power
Active and Passive powers

Power that is realized in action
Power that is being realized even when it is not being realized in action

Social vs. structural powers

Social power is power exercised (actively or passively) by one or more social agents.
But social power depends on practical coordination among social agents in a net-like organization. In such a case then, it is power that is never in one person’s hands alone.

title: Epistemic Injustice
text:
Identity Power
Central to social power is identity power since social power is dependent on the kinds of social exchanges that are possible between agents.
At the center of this are testimonial exchanges which rely on “shared imaginative conceptions of social identity:” identity powers.
Faulty judgments of a speaker will hinder these kinds of exchanges. We can apply this to the case of the victim. The victim is not able to defend her belief that she is not a victim because her judgment of her friend as speaker hinders her ability to explain herself. Additionally, her friend’s faulty judgment of her as a speaker also hinders her friend’s ability to accept her explanation.

title: Art Interpretive Injustice
text: Prosecutorial use of rap music as example of art-interpretive injustice

title: Art Interpretive Injustice
text:
Testimonial and Hermeneutical Injustice

Testimonial Injustice: “listeners extend the wrong degree of credibility”

Testimony of the speaker is called into question because of the identity of the speaker
But the victim in the Medina case does not suffer from credibility deficit because his lyrics were used as credible evidence
However, the victim’s lyrics were taken as testimony rather than artistic expression

Hermeneutical Injustice: “when someone’s own experience is obscured because the available concepts distort it or render it inscrutable”

Social experiences “obscured from collective understanding”
This is caused by structural identity prejudice in the “collective hermeneutical” resource
Analogous to the Medina case, the prosecutors misdescribe the victim’s experience (Fricker 2016, 167).
